description.narrative: The project will contribute to make the link between climate change, environmental degradation and urban poverty visible through education, advocacy and increased dialogue so that municipal public policies address this problem adequately, actively involving civil society, youth and women's organizations in the identification of suitable actions and strategies.

WWF Bolivia har lämnat in ett programförslag till Sveriges ambassad i Bolivia för programmet “Soluciones Urbanas con Accion Ciudadana” för stöd för 20 MSEK mellan åren 2018-2020. Programmet ämnar öka civila samhällets kunskap om och inflytande i hållbar lokal stadsplanering och bidra till att synliggöra och öka kunskaperna kring kopplingen mellan klimatförändringar, miljöförstöring och urban fattigdom. WWF har i utvecklandet av programmet använt sig av den multidimensionella fattigdomsanalysen (MDPA) vilket har gett till en djupare förståelse av kontexten, problematiken och en tydlig identifiering av målgrupperna. Programmet innefattar tre resultatområden för att uppnå det övergripande syftet: 1) Barn och ungdomar i städer och speciellt fattiga områden i de utvalda kommunerna har kunskap om, kan analysera och känner sig delaktiga i frågor kring klimatförändringar och urbana miljöfrågor samt dess effekter på urban fattigdom. 2) Kommuner, ungdoms och kvinnoorganisationer i fattiga områden föreslår och implementerar urbana lösningar fokuserade kring resiliens kopplat till klimatförändringar och miljöfrågor inom områden som vatten, sophantering, transport och energi vilka kan bidra till minskad urban fattigdom 3) Civilsamhället (sociala gräsrotsorganisationer, universitet, frivilligorganisationer), företag och relevanta offentliga institutioner påverkar lokala policyers som möjliggör en utveckling av hållbara städer och bidrar till den nationella agendan för urban utveckling.

WWF Bolivia has submitted a proposal to the embassy of Sweden called "urban solutions with citizen action". The proposal for funding is 20MSEK between the years 2018-2020. The project will contribute to make visible the link between climate change and environmental and urban poverty so that municipal public policies address this problem adequately, actively involving civil society, children, youth and women's organizations in the identification of suitable actions and strategies.

participating-org.narrative: WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Bolivia
WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Bolivia

tag.narrative: 11.3 - By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
11.3 - Till 2030 verka för en inkluderande och hållbar urbanisering samt förbättra kapaciteten för deltagandebaserad, integrerad och hållbar planering och förvaltning av bosättningar i alla länder.

11.5 - By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.

11.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet dödsfall och antalet människor som drabbas av katastrofer, inklusive vattenrelaterade katastrofer. Även tillse att de direkta ekonomiska förlusterna till följd av sådana katastrofer, i form av lägre global BNP, minskar väsentligt. Särskilt fokus bör ligga på att skydda de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer.
11.6 - By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.
11.6 - Till 2030 minska städernas negativa miljöpåverkan per person, bland annat genom att ägna särskild uppmärksamhet åt luftkvalitet samt hantering av kommunalt och annat avfall.
11.7 - By 2030, provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible, green and public spaces, in particular for women and children, older persons and persons with disabilities.

11.7 - Senast 2030 tillhandahålla universell tillgång till säkra, inkluderande och tillgängliga grönområden och offentliga platser, i synnerhet för kvinnor och barn, äldre personer och personer med funktionsnedsättning.
13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.
15.9 - By 2020, integrate ecosystem and biodiversity values into national and local planning, development processes, poverty reduction strategies and accounts.
15.9 - Senast 2020 integrera ekosystemens och den biologiska mångfaldens värden i nationella och lokala planerings- och utvecklingsprocesser, i strategier för fattigdomsminskning samt i räkenskaper.

description.narrative:
The design of the project oriented a large part of its efforts in opening real and concrete spaces for participation, challenging the population to be part of the solutions to the growing urban problems. Despite the limitations presented by the pandemic and lock down, the project has managed to achieve important results. Some of the virtual adaptations made have been able to reach more people than originally planned for and the project team has shown an adequate capacity to adapt the project to the circumstances. Below are some examples of the results.
The Fund Allocation mechanism in form of challenge funds, Citizen Initiatives Fund (FIC) and Municipal Competitive Fund (FCM), encourage the population to identify, design and execute projects to address gaps that increase vulnerabilities. Through these instruments, the project financed and executed 20 projects by FIC, executed mainly by groups of young environmentalists to face the degradation of nature, encouraging, and awakening among the population their support for its conservation, restoration and rehabilitation. Another group of FIC financed projects are executed with women´s organizations in situations of poverty proposed to improve their work, technical and / or training conditions to strengthen their organization and thus expand their options and opportunities to have an impact on their economic situation. The FCM, with its multi-stakeholder and multi-level approach, joined efforts with the municipality, universities, non-governmental organizations, youth groups, to make the expectations of the population come true, through the opportunity to propose solutions to environmental problems. At first, it attended projects on basic water and sewerage services and solid waste management due to the strong relationship and incidence between urban poverty and environmental problems, through the financing of 4 projects. In a second phase and to face risks due heavy climate events and landslides, the restoration and expansion of natural spaces and the saving of natural resources, 4 new projects were financed with an emphasis on nature-based solutions.
Simultaneously with the previous actions and on the horizon of building an environmental citizenship, the project's environmental education strategy was taking shape, based on three main components; actions in educational units articulating environmental issues to the contents of the national base curriculum operationalized through the Socio-Productive and Community Projects (PSP), implementing 46 of these projects, which due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic and the confinement and implementation of the modality were unable to continue during the 2020-2021 school administration. The project developed and validated with the teachers a pedagogical methodology appropriate to the virtual modality: "that of the inverted class", with virtual educational supports and content and hosted on our website.To do this, digital educational material was developed for primary and secondary level teachers. 200 teachers were capacitated and the word spread about the platform; beyond the expectations of the project team.
A second component of the educational strategy was consolidated around three Municipal Protected Areas (Curichi La Madre in Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Urban Biopark in Tarija and Ibare-Mamoré in Trinidad), the project took on the challenge of safeguarding, restoring, strengthening and turning them into learning and research spaces that inspire and connect the population with nature and life. An example is the investigation on urban birds and native trees in the urban Biopark in the city of Tarija through a university thesis; a work that had the technical support provided by professionals from the Bio Park and a university professor. A second investigation was carried out by technicians from the Bio Park, also with the support from university professors and invited professionals, that made it possible to identify seasonal and migratory birds in the area. Both investigations were presented to the public through social networks and printed material. With the results of both investigations, virtual workshops were organized for university students, young activists, scout groups, etc. Later, several contests were organized such as: bird feeder design, children's story scripts, urban bird photography contest. A virtual course for small ornithologists crowned the activities in the area. More than 950 children and young people participated in these activities. Another example of work is the initiative "We Like Science" in association with young volunteers, were workshops were organized in the three areas of Santa Cruz: La Pampa de la isla, El Plan 3000, and Villa 1ro de Mayo, bringing together a social fabric characterized by its great cultural diversity due to migration processes. The purpose of the workshops was to raise interest in science among young people and help them encountering answers or solutions to various environmental problems, while also supporting them in their personal deveopment and their professionalization. The contents of the We Like Science was adapted to workshops, and two virtual workshops were organized. In total, there were 822 participants from all over Bolivia assisting the two workshops. At the end of the workshops the young people, dived in small groups, proposed a huge number of possible solutions to environmental problems in their surroundings.
The third component of the environmental education strategy was developed with the Environmental Education Centers (CEA), i.e. municipal spaces equipped to deepen the knowledge and understanding of environmental issues, biodiversity and climate change, based on a relevant educational offer, contextualized and playful, formal and non-formal that promotes the construction of an environmental citizenship. The project has supported 4 environmental education centers (in La Paz, Tarija, Santa Cruz, and Trinidad), which articulated all the components of the project, being the meeting point of all the actors including the participants of the Competitive Funds (FIC and FCM), youth and women's groups, environmental institutions, schools and teachers. During the pandemic, the CEA through its virtual platforms organized various activities, highlighting the cycle of green cinema, in which documentaries from the WWF network and others referring to environmental and climate change issues were broadcast, more than 8,000 thousand people followed this program cycle. Videos were broadcast on solid waste management, efficient use of water and biodiversity. The CEA in coordination with young environmental activists organized the first volunteer days in the city of Tarija, 22 organizations and youth groups participated in it, an exhibition fair, in a central square of the city, allowed to know the actions, works and concerns of the young volunteers.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
